values.description:
This script is able to work with directories for 'software-release' which use a directory layout based on directory-per-distribution instead of branches.

Is basically the same as debbuild but using the new layout for multidistributions ([see the gazebo example](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo-release/pull-request/5/support-to-host-multi-distributions-in-the/diff))
values.title: New debbuild to support multidistribution

summary.html:
This script is able to work with directories for 'software-release' which use a directory layout based on directory-per-distribution instead of branches.

values.description:
Support to define the arch directory to use in new multidistribution release repos layouts, which host one distribution per directory.

Backwards compatibility with current single release repos is done using the 'ubuntu' as RELEASE_REPO_DIRECTORY, which is done by default if omitted.
values.title: Multidistribution support for debbuild.sh

summary.raw:
Support to define the arch directory to use in new multidistribution release repos layouts, which host one distribution per directory.

Backwards compatibility with current single release repos is done using the 'ubuntu' as RELEASE_REPO_DIRECTORY, which is done by default if omitted.
summary.html:
Support to define the arch directory to use in new multidistribution release repos layouts, which host one distribution per directory.

Backwards compatibility with current single release repos is done using the 'ubuntu' as RELEASE_REPO_DIRECTORY, which is done by default if omitted.

values.description:
This pull request implements the support for installing proper DRI packages inside the pbuilder (chroot) environment. The problem is that to get proper DRI support inside a chroot, the chroot should have the same kernel DRI support installed that one running in the host machine.

Code to detect Nvidia packages installed (could be nvidia-{number}, nvidia-current, ...) is a bit hacky but seems to work. At the moment detecting ATI will imply to install fglrx (it can be improve in the future).

Installing the proper packages to get support seems to fix most of our issue with graphical tests failing in jenkins: 

* See [testing case for gazebo_1.5 in vrc_real machine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo_1.5/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-glsupport-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/4/console)
* See [testing case for gazebo_1.5 in ati machine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo_1.5/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-glsupport-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/1/console)
* Experimental case for [drcsim default using gazebo default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/drcsim-default-gazebo-default-glsupport-precise-amd64/6/console)
values.title: Install proper DRI support for jenkins pbuilders (build.sh)

summary.raw:
This pull request implements the support for installing proper DRI packages inside the pbuilder (chroot) environment. The problem is that to get proper DRI support inside a chroot, the chroot should have the same kernel DRI support installed that one running in the host machine.

Code to detect Nvidia packages installed (could be nvidia-{number}, nvidia-current, ...) is a bit hacky but seems to work. At the moment detecting ATI will imply to install fglrx (it can be improve in the future).

Installing the proper packages to get support seems to fix most of our issue with graphical tests failing in jenkins: 

* See [testing case for gazebo_1.5 in vrc_real machine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo_1.5/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-glsupport-precise-amd64-gpu-vrc/4/console)
* See [testing case for gazebo_1.5 in ati machine](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo_1.5/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-glsupport-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/1/console)
* Experimental case for [drcsim default using gazebo default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/drcsim-default-gazebo-default-glsupport-precise-amd64/6/console)
summary.html:
This pull request implements the support for installing proper DRI packages inside the pbuilder (chroot) environment. The problem is that to get proper DRI support inside a chroot, the chroot should have the same kernel DRI support installed that one running in the host machine.

Code to detect Nvidia packages installed (could be nvidia-{number}, nvidia-current, ...) is a bit hacky but seems to work. At the moment detecting ATI will imply to install fglrx (it can be improve in the future).

Installing the proper packages to get support seems to fix most of our issue with graphical tests failing in jenkins:

  • See testing case for gazebo_1.5 in vrc_real machine
  • See testing case for gazebo_1.5 in ati machine
  • Experimental case for drcsim default using gazebo default

values.description:
Initial support for nightly builds

debbuild-base is modified to support nightly mode (VERSION=nightly) which will imply:

* Use the nightly branches from {software}-release repos. In these branches changelogs are static templates with xxxxx to be changed by dynamically generated version and ddddd by generated dates.
* It will checkout the default branch of {software} instead of using a .tar.bz2 

A test was done using gazebo: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-fake-debbuild/3/console

Also release.py took a new --nightly parameter which will skip the tar.bz2 generation and adjust some parameters to nightly mode needed values.
values.title: Support for nightly builds

summary.raw:
Initial support for nightly builds

debbuild-base is modified to support nightly mode (VERSION=nightly) which will imply:

* Use the nightly branches from {software}-release repos. In these branches changelogs are static templates with xxxxx to be changed by dynamically generated version and ddddd by generated dates.
* It will checkout the default branch of {software} instead of using a .tar.bz2 

A test was done using gazebo: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-fake-debbuild/3/console

Also release.py took a new --nightly parameter which will skip the tar.bz2 generation and adjust some parameters to nightly mode needed values.
summary.html:
Initial support for nightly builds

debbuild-base is modified to support nightly mode (VERSION=nightly) which will imply:

  • Use the nightly branches from {software}-release repos. In these branches changelogs are static templates with xxxxx to be changed by dynamically generated version and ddddd by generated dates.
  • It will checkout the default branch of {software} instead of using a .tar.bz2

A test was done using gazebo: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-fake-debbuild/3/console

Also release.py took a new --nightly parameter which will skip the tar.bz2 generation and adjust some parameters to nightly mode needed values.

values.description:
Auto remove old copies of nightly packages keeping latest three.

We only need to remove the .deb from assets directory since we don't upload tarballs (obviously) and reprepro takes care of remove previous copy of a package when uploading a new one.

About this pull request, note that only after a scp, we get old copies of current package being aware of ARCH and DISTRO and remove them.

A couple of tricks used:

1. Extra grep to check for nightly substring inside package alias. This is an extra check but I don't want to remove something which shouldn't. 
1. ``ls -t`` to order by filesystem time instead of  trust on filenames.

And I know that this code duplication starts to look like need a refactor, yes, it is in my todo list.
values.title: Auto remove old nightly packages copies

summary.raw:
Auto remove old copies of nightly packages keeping latest three.

We only need to remove the .deb from assets directory since we don't upload tarballs (obviously) and reprepro takes care of remove previous copy of a package when uploading a new one.

About this pull request, note that only after a scp, we get old copies of current package being aware of ARCH and DISTRO and remove them.

A couple of tricks used:

1. Extra grep to check for nightly substring inside package alias. This is an extra check but I don't want to remove something which shouldn't. 
1. ``ls -t`` to order by filesystem time instead of  trust on filenames.

And I know that this code duplication starts to look like need a refactor, yes, it is in my todo list.
summary.html:
Auto remove old copies of nightly packages keeping latest three.

We only need to remove the .deb from assets directory since we don't upload tarballs (obviously) and reprepro takes care of remove previous copy of a package when uploading a new one.

About this pull request, note that only after a scp, we get old copies of current package being aware of ARCH and DISTRO and remove them.

A couple of tricks used:

  1. Extra grep to check for nightly substring inside package alias. This is an extra check but I don't want to remove something which shouldn't.
  2. ls -t to order by filesystem time instead of trust on filenames.

And I know that this code duplication starts to look like need a refactor, yes, it is in my todo list.

values.description:
Basic code and instructions to run our jenkins scripts from desktop machines. Some features:

1. It allows to generate .deb in the local machine.
1. It allows to use a local release-tool repository, useful when developing release-tools and want a quick test without commit and run in jenkins.
1. It allows to use a local software code repository, useful to be sure there is nothing broken from a clean installation.
values.title: Initial support to run OSRF jenkins scripts without jenkins

summary.raw:
Basic code and instructions to run our jenkins scripts from desktop machines. Some features:

1. It allows to generate .deb in the local machine.
1. It allows to use a local release-tool repository, useful when developing release-tools and want a quick test without commit and run in jenkins.
1. It allows to use a local software code repository, useful to be sure there is nothing broken from a clean installation.
summary.html:
Basic code and instructions to run our jenkins scripts from desktop machines. Some features:

  1. It allows to generate .deb in the local machine.
  2. It allows to use a local release-tool repository, useful when developing release-tools and want a quick test without commit and run in jenkins.
  3. It allows to use a local software code repository, useful to be sure there is nothing broken from a clean installation.

values.description:
Already in use from a branch but let's merge this into default.

This implements the philosophy of separate the creation of a package and it's process of uploading to the OSRF repo and gazebosim.

* debbuild-base was modified to take care of only build the packages and export them to $WORKSPACE/pkgs/
* nightly-cleanup is run every time that repository uploader ends and take care of keeping only the last 5 generated nightly packages.
* repository_uploader is the one that takes the pkgs from debbuild and upload it to repo/gazebosim.
values.title: Split package generation and package uploading

summary.raw:
Already in use from a branch but let's merge this into default.

This implements the philosophy of separate the creation of a package and it's process of uploading to the OSRF repo and gazebosim.

* debbuild-base was modified to take care of only build the packages and export them to $WORKSPACE/pkgs/
* nightly-cleanup is run every time that repository uploader ends and take care of keeping only the last 5 generated nightly packages.
* repository_uploader is the one that takes the pkgs from debbuild and upload it to repo/gazebosim.
summary.html:
Already in use from a branch but let's merge this into default.

This implements the philosophy of separate the creation of a package and it's process of uploading to the OSRF repo and gazebosim.

  • debbuild-base was modified to take care of only build the packages and export them to $WORKSPACE/pkgs/
  • nightly-cleanup is run every time that repository uploader ends and take care of keeping only the last 5 generated nightly packages.
  • repository_uploader is the one that takes the pkgs from debbuild and upload it to repo/gazebosim.

With these changes, I can use release.py to release code from git repos (e.g., https://github.com/osrf/opensplice).  It's not pretty, but then there's much that's attractive about release.py :)

For consideration by @_jrivero_
values.title: Add minimal support for releasing from git repos

summary.raw:
With these changes, I can use release.py to release code from git repos (e.g., https://github.com/osrf/opensplice).  It's not pretty, but then there's much that's attractive about release.py :)

For consideration by @_jrivero_
summary.html:
With these changes, I can use release.py to release code from git repos (e.g., https://github.com/osrf/opensplice). It's not pretty, but then there's much that's attractive about release.py :)

For consideration by @jrivero

values.description:
I've implemented a couple of new flags into release.py:

* **--drcsim-multiros:** in order to launch debbuilder when using one ubuntu platform but several ROS distributions on it (precise/groovy, precise/hydro). Need when releasing osrf-comon, sandia-hand and drcsim (which use ROS_DISTRO param in jenkins).
* **---no-generate-source-file:** useful when releasing third party stuff (like bullet, bloom, etc) when we don't want to generate a source file.
values.title: DRCSim ROS support and no-generate-source-file to release.py

summary.raw:
I've implemented a couple of new flags into release.py:

* **--drcsim-multiros:** in order to launch debbuilder when using one ubuntu platform but several ROS distributions on it (precise/groovy, precise/hydro). Need when releasing osrf-comon, sandia-hand and drcsim (which use ROS_DISTRO param in jenkins).
* **---no-generate-source-file:** useful when releasing third party stuff (like bullet, bloom, etc) when we don't want to generate a source file.
summary.html:
I've implemented a couple of new flags into release.py:

  • --drcsim-multiros: in order to launch debbuilder when using one ubuntu platform but several ROS distributions on it (precise/groovy, precise/hydro). Need when releasing osrf-comon, sandia-hand and drcsim (which use ROS_DISTRO param in jenkins).
  • ---no-generate-source-file: useful when releasing third party stuff (like bullet, bloom, etc) when we don't want to generate a source file.

values.title: Support for release from ignitionrobotics repositories

summary.html: I've added a new flag --ignition-repo to our release.py script needed when releasing software from ignition repositories. Also support in debbuild jenkins script.

values.description: Check for the non presence of underscores in package name (if no alias is present) or package alias.
values.title: Security check to avoid releasing packages using underscores

summary.raw: Check for the non presence of underscores in package name (if no alias is present) or package alias.
summary.html: Check for the non presence of underscores in package name (if no alias is present) or package alias.

values.description:
Define dart4 for jenkins builds and start using it for our -any- builds.

I've created an [experimental job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/) for the current dart4 PR.
values.title: Support for dart4 in jenkins builds

summary.raw:
Define dart4 for jenkins builds and start using it for our -any- builds.

I've created an [experimental job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/) for the current dart4 PR.
summary.html:
Define dart4 for jenkins builds and start using it for our -any- builds.

I've created an experimental job for the current dart4 PR.

values.description: Looks like merging pull request #44 was not a good idea. It is broken for -any- jobs which don't know what version of dart should be using. For example, an any job against gazebo_3.1 is using (like all) DART-4.1 and broken. I'm disabling dart until tomorrow, to find a good solution for this.
values.title: Disable DART until find a good solution for -any- jobs

summary.raw: Looks like merging pull request #44 was not a good idea. It is broken for -any- jobs which don't know what version of dart should be using. For example, an any job against gazebo_3.1 is using (like all) DART-4.1 and broken. I'm disabling dart until tomorrow, to find a good solution for this.
summary.html: Looks like merging pull request #44 was not a good idea. It is broken for -any- jobs which don't know what version of dart should be using. For example, an any job against gazebo_3.1 is using (like all) DART-4.1 and broken. I'm disabling dart until tomorrow, to find a good solution for this.

values.description:
Look in /tmp/.X11-unix and then search for processes that have a matching display name.

If it works, we should put this in a separate script and reference it from the other scripts.
values.title: Test for fixing X detection

summary.raw:
Look in /tmp/.X11-unix and then search for processes that have a matching display name.

If it works, we should put this in a separate script and reference it from the other scripts.
summary.html:
Look in /tmp/.X11-unix and then search for processes that have a matching display name.

If it works, we should put this in a separate script and reference it from the other scripts.

values.description:
Two things:

 * improve detection of display
 * fail job if no GPU is detected when using GPU_SUPPORT_NEEDED, now used by all gui jobs. 


It includes change in pull request #46.

Also remove duplicate set DISPLAY code and unify it in only one place.
values.title: Make GUI jobs fail under the no presence of a valid GPU

summary.raw:
Two things:

 * improve detection of display
 * fail job if no GPU is detected when using GPU_SUPPORT_NEEDED, now used by all gui jobs. 


It includes change in pull request #46.

Also remove duplicate set DISPLAY code and unify it in only one place.
summary.html:
Two things:

  • improve detection of display
  • fail job if no GPU is detected when using GPU_SUPPORT_NEEDED, now used by all gui jobs.

It includes change in pull request #46.

Also remove duplicate set DISPLAY code and unify it in only one place.

values.title: Support for deprecating raring ubuntu distro
Use sdformat prerelease until 2.0.1 is released
Support to use old-archive.ubuntu.com for old distros
